items.title: Hidden brain signal reveals Alzheimer’s years before symptoms
items.excerpt: TSPO, a key biomarker of brain inflammation, could help detect Alzheimer's disease years before memory loss and other symptoms set in - potentially leading to advances in how the disease is diagnosed and treated, according to a study published in Acta Neuropathologica .

items.title: Dementia-like clumps found in cells before cancer strikes
items.excerpt: Cancer Research UK-funded scientists have uncovered dementia-like behavior in pancreas cells at risk of turning into cancer. The findings provide clues that could help in the treatment and prevention of pancreatic cancer, a difficult-to-treat disease linked to 6,900 deaths in …

items.title: Can meditation apps really reduce stress, anxiety, and insomnia?
items.excerpt: Do you have a meditation app on your smartphone, computer or wearable device? Well, you're not alone.

items.title: Why alcohol blocks the liver from healing, even after you quit
items.excerpt: Excessive alcohol consumption can disrupt the liver's unique regenerative abilities by trapping cells in limbo between their functional and regenerative states, even after a patient stops drinking, researchers at University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign and collaborators at Duk…

items.title: When cancer cells feel squeezed, they become more dangerous
items.excerpt: Cancer cells are notoriously flexible, taking on new features as they move around the body. Many of these changes are due to epigenetic modifications, which influence how DNA is packaged, and not due to mutations in the DNA itself. Such modifications are difficult to target fo…

items.title: Want a younger brain? Harvard researchers say eat like this
items.excerpt: Following a green-Mediterranean diet -- which includes green tea and the aquatic plant Mankai -- is associated with slower brain aging, according to a study.

items.title: Sneezing from cats or dust? Safe UV light may neutralize allergens in minutes
items.excerpt: Cats. Dust mites. Mold. Trees.

items.title: New crystal camera lets doctors see inside the body like never before
items.excerpt: Physicians rely on nuclear medicine scans, like SPECT scans, to watch the heart pump, track blood flow and detect diseases hidden deep inside the body. But today's scanners depend on expensive detectors that are difficult to make.

items.title: Childhood plastic exposure could be fueling obesity, infertility, and asthma
items.excerpt: Childhood exposure to chemicals used to make plastic household items presents growing health risks that can extend long into adulthood, experts from NYU Langone Health report.

items.title: A hormone that silences the immune system may unlock new cancer treatments
items.excerpt: Researchers at UT Southwestern Medical Center have discovered how a hormone interacts with a receptor on the surface of immune cells to shield cancer cells from the body's natural defenses. The findings, published in Nature Immunology , could lead to new immunotherapy approach…

items.title: Your pancreas may be making its own version of Ozempic
items.excerpt: A new study from Duke University School of Medicine is challenging long-standing views on blood sugar regulation -- and pointing to a surprising new ally in the fight against type 2 diabetes.

items.title: This stunning X-ray advance could help detect cancer earlier
items.excerpt: When German physicist Wilhelm Röntgen discovered X-rays in the late 1800s while experimenting with cathode ray tubes, it was a breakthrough that transformed science and medicine. So much so that the basic concept remains in use today. But a team of researchers at Sandia Nation…

items.title: Simple therapies outperform drugs for knee arthritis pain relief
items.excerpt: Knee braces, water therapy and exercise are the most promising non-drug therapies for treating knee osteoarthritis, according to a new meta-analysis publishing June 18, 2025 in the open-access journal PLOS One by Yuan Luo of the First People's Hospital of Neijiang, China.

items.title: Scientists reveal the everyday habits that may shield you from dementia
items.excerpt: An estimated 7.2 million Americans over age 65 currently live with Alzheimer's disease (AD). That number is expected to nearly double to 13.8 million by 2060. These increases reflect more than demographic shifts; they point to a growing public health crisis that requires a new…

items.title: New breath sensor detects diabetes quickly and easily
items.excerpt: In the U.S., one in five of the 37 million adults who has diabetes doesn't know it. Current methods of diagnosing diabetes and prediabetes usually require a visit to a doctor's office or lab work, both of which can be expensive and time-consuming. Now, diagnosing diabetes and …

items.title: Clear skin in a week with this breakthrough acne patch
items.excerpt: Waking up with a pimple is no longer cause for panic, thanks to pimple patches -- small, sticker-like bandages that cover and help heal the unwanted zit. A team of researchers publishing in ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces has designed a two-stage pimple patch set with an ar…

items.title: Scientists uncover exercise’s secret hunger-busting molecule
items.excerpt: Researchers at Baylor College ofMedicine, Jan and Dan Duncan Neurological Research Institute (Duncan NRI) at Texas Children's Hospital, Stanford University School of Medicine and collaborating institutions provide new insights into how exercise helps lose weight. The researche…

items.title: Scientists discover cancer’s hidden power to accelerate aging
items.excerpt: A new study led by a team of researchers at Moffitt Cancer Center reveals that lymphoma can accelerate the biological aging of the immune system and other tissues, providing new insight into how cancer reshapes the body beyond tumor growth.

items.title: Rogue DNA rings may be the secret spark driving deadly brain cancer
items.excerpt: An international team of scientists has revealed how rogue rings of DNA that float outside of our chromosomes -- known as extrachromosomal DNA, or ecDNA -- can drive the growth of a large proportion of glioblastomas, the most common and aggressive adult brain cancer. The disco…

items.title: Goodbye colonoscopy? Simple stool test detects 90% of colorectal cancers
items.excerpt: Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death worldwide. If detected early, it can be efficiently treated, but the cost and discomfort of colonoscopies -- the main diagnostic method currently in use -- often result in delayed diagnosis. Using machine learning a…

items.title: Stanford scientists reveal simple shift that could prevent strokes and obesity nationwide
items.excerpt: Every spring, Americans dutifully adjust their clocks forward to daylight saving time, and every fall, back to standard time -- but no one seems very happy about it. The biannual time shift is not only inconvenient, it's also known to be acutely bad for our health. The collect…

items.title: Scientists reverse stroke damage with stem cells
items.excerpt: Stem cell transplantation can reverse stroke damage, researchers at the University of Zurich report. Its beneficial effects include regeneration of neurons and restoration of motor functions, marking a milestone in the treatment of brain disorders.

items.title: Ozempic, Wegovy and Mounjaro makes food taste sweeter and saltier, and that may quiet cravings
items.excerpt: New research being presented at the Annual Meeting of the European Association for the Study of Diabetes (EASD) in Vienna, Austria (September 15-19) shows that some individuals who are taking Ozempic, Wegovy or Mounjaro find that foods taste sweeter or saltier than before.

items.title: Why so many young kids with ADHD are getting the wrong treatment
items.excerpt: Young children with attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder often receive medication just after being diagnosed, which contravenes treatment guidelines endorsed by the American Academy of Pediatrics, a Stanford Medicine-led study has found.

items.title: Stress measured in hair could predict depression and anxiety in children
items.excerpt: Long-term stress levels, measured through hair samples, may provide important clues about mental health risks in children with chronic physical illnesses (CPI), according to new research from the University of Waterloo.

items.title: Semaglutide may silence the food noise in your head
items.excerpt: New research being presented at the Annual Meeting of the European Association for the Study of Diabetes (EASD) in Vienna, Austria (September 15-19) shows that individuals who are taking semaglutide for weight loss experience less food noise than before.

items.title: New drug could be first to stop deadly fatty liver disease
items.excerpt: Researchers at University of California San Diego School of Medicine have identified a new investigational drug that shows promise in treating metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH), a serious form of fatty liver disease linked to obesity and type 2 diabetes t…

items.title: Eating Mediterranean could be the secret to healthy gums
items.excerpt: People living in the UK and following a diet close to the Mediterranean diet are more likely to have better gum health, with potentially lower amounts of gum disease and inflammation.

items.title: Scientists test an anti-aging cream that actually works
items.excerpt: Against the backdrop of high market demand for effective anti-ageing cosmetics, a team of Chinese researchers assessed the clinical effectiveness of a 0.1 % pterostilbene-containing skincare emulsion against a control emulsion over 28 days with 31 participants.

items.title: Millions have diabetes without knowing it
items.excerpt: A large portion of the global population with diabetes remains undiagnosed or is not receiving optimal care, according to a new study published in The Lancet Diabetes & Endocrinology . The Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) at the University of Washington Schoo…

items.title: Half of adults suffer from dry eyes, but most never get help
items.excerpt: Dry eyes can cause significant discomfort, and the symptoms become more common as we age. However, until now, it was unclear what proportion of the population suffered from the condition, with estimates ranging from 5-50%.

items.title: Guava’s secret molecule could fight liver cancer
items.excerpt: You may not be aware that most of the medicines that have been approved for treatment are rooted in nature.

items.title: Daily eye drops could make reading glasses obsolete
items.excerpt: Everybody develops presbyopia as they age - a difficulty in focusing on near objects and text - and often have to resort to reading glasses. However, the solution might be as simple as using special eye drops two or three times a day.

items.title: Cannabis use may quadruple diabetes risk
items.excerpt: Cannabis use is linked to an almost quadrupling in the risk of developing diabetes, according to an analysis of real-world data from over 4 million adults, being presented at this year’s Annual Meeting of The European Association for the Study of Diabetes (EASD) in Vienna, Aus…

items.title: Being too thin can be deadlier than being overweight, Danish study reveals
items.excerpt: It is possible to be "fat but fit," new research being presented at the annual meeting of the European Association for the Study of Diabetes (EASD) in Vienna, Austria (September 15-19) suggests.

items.title: Sleepless nights may raise dementia risk by 40%, Mayo Clinic reveals
items.excerpt: Highlights:

items.title: Most quit breakthrough weight-loss drug within a year
items.excerpt: The new class of anti-obesity drugs, glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1RAs), is proving remarkably effective at helping individuals lose weight. However, a new population-wide study being presented at this year's Annual Meeting of The European Association for the…

items.title: AI can now predict who will go blind, years before doctors can
items.excerpt: Researchers have successfully used artificial intelligence (AI) to predict which patients need treatment to stabilise their corneas and preserve their eyesight, in a study presented today (Sunday) at the 43 rd Congress of the European Society of Cataract and Refractive Surgeon…

items.title: 1 in 8 Americans have already tried Ozempic and similar weight loss medications
items.excerpt: Nearly 12% of Americans have used GLP-1 drugs for weight loss, including about one-fifth of women aged 50 to 64, according to a new RAND report.

items.title: Surprising giant DNA discovery may be linked to gum disease and cancer
items.excerpt: Researchers including those at the University of Tokyo have made a surprising discovery hiding in people's mouths: Inocles, giant DNA elements that had previously escaped detection. These appear to play a central role in helping bacteria adapt to the constantly changing enviro…

items.title: Scientists just found out forever chemicals are shockingly acidic
items.excerpt: One of the ways that per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) earn their "forever chemical" nickname and persist in the environment is their acidity.

items.title: Hidden gut molecule found to wreck kidneys
items.excerpt: A molecule made by bacteria in the gut can hitch a ride to the kidneys, where it sets off a chain reaction of inflammation, scarring and fibrosis -- a serious complication of diabetes and a leading cause of kidney failure -- according to a new study from researchers at the Uni…

items.title: Fatty liver breakthrough: A safe, cheap vitamin shows promise
items.excerpt: Approximately 30% of the global population is affected by metabolic-associated fatty liver disease (MASLD), a condition that previously lacked targeted treatments. In a groundbreaking discovery, researchers have identified a genetic factor that exacerbates the disease, and rem…

items.title: One daily habit could save you from chronic back pain
items.excerpt: A major study has investigated the relationship between walking and the risk of developing chronic lower back problems. The findings could save the healthcare system significant amounts of money while also alleviating many people's back pain - if we just follow the simple advi…

items.title: Your morning coffee could secretly be weakening antibiotics
items.excerpt: Ingredients of our daily diet - including caffeine - can influence the resistance of bacteria to antibiotics. This has been shown in a new study by a team of researchers at the Universities of Tübingen and Würzburg led by Professor Ana Rita Brochado. They discovered bacteria s…
